https://prez.dev/description.@value: A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

The branch of geology that deals with the form (geometry), spatial arrangement, and internal structure of the rocks, and especially with the description, representation, and analysis of structures (e.g. bedding, folds, faults and fractures), chiefly on a meso- to macroscopic scale. The subject is similar to tectonics, but the latter is generally used for the broader regional or historical phases.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: The branches of geology that, combined, focus on the manifestation of plate tectonic motions in the deformation of Earth's crust and lithosphere, from the scale of mountain ranges to individual faults and folds, and on timescales from deep Earth history to present-day tectonism and associated natural hazards.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from: https://epsci.stanford.edu/structural-geology-tectonics-geomechanics.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: The branches of geology that, combined, focus on the manifestation of plate tectonic motions in the deformation of Earth's crust and lithosphere, from the scale of mountain ranges to individual faults and folds, and on timescales from deep Earth history to present-day tectonism and associated natural hazards.

The branch of geology dealing with the broad architecture of the outer part of the Earth, i.e. the regional assembling of structural or deformational features, a study of their mutual relations, origin and historical evolution. It is closely related to structural geology, with which the distinctions are blurred, but tectonics generally deals with larger features.
